#Text=William
#Text=Cotton ( bishop )
#Text=Monument and effigy of Bishop
#Text=William Cotton in Exeter Cathedral
#Text=Arms of Cotton ( Ancient ) : Argent , a bend sable between three pellets , as seen on top of the monument of Bishop William Cotton in Exeter Cathedral
#Text=William Cotton
#Text=( died 1621 ) was Bishop of Exeter , in Devon , from 1598 to his death in 1621 .
#Text=Origins
#Text=William Cotton was brought up in Finchley , Middlesex . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was the eldest son of John Cotton , a Citizen of the City of London by his wife Pery Cheyne .

#Text=John Cotton was the third son of Richard Cotton ( died 1534 ) of Hamstall Ridware in Staffordshire , descended from William Cotton ( fl.1378,1400 ) lord of the manor of Cotton in Cheshire , by his wife Agnes de Ridware , daughter and heiress of Walter de Ridware , lord of the manor of Hamstall Ridware . [ 2 ]

#Text=The junior branch of the Cotton family descended from Agnes de Ridware adopted the armorials of Ridware ( Azure , an eagle displayed argent ) [ 3 ] in lieu of their paternal arms of Cotton , which junior branch included Sir Robert Cotton , 1st Baronet ( 1570 – 1631 ) of Conington in Huntingdonshire , founder of the Cottonian Library .

#Text=The senior branch , of which Bishop Cotton was a member , retained the ancient arms of Cotton ( Argent , a bend sable between three pellets ) , as is visible on the monuments in Exeter Cathedral to Bishop William Cotton himself and on that of his grandson Edward Cotton ( died 1675 ) , Treasurer of Exeter Cathedral . [ 4 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=He graduated M.A. at Queens ' College , Cambridge in 1575 . [ 5 ]
#Text=He was Archdeacon of Lewes , in Sussex , from 1578 to 1598 , when he became Bishop of Exeter . [ 6 ]
#Text=He was confrontational in his relationship with the Puritans of his diocese .

#Text=He objected strongly to the nomination of John Hazard as Bodley lecturer . [ 7 ] Cotton suspected Hazard of " false doctrine " , of intrusion into congregations that already had preachers , and association with John Traske , the seventh-day Sabbatarian , which Hazard denied .
#Text=George Abbot
#Text=, Archbishop of Canterbury , had licensed Hazard to preach , but Cotton was not satisfied with that . [ 8 ] [ 9 ]
#Text=Marriage and children
#Text=He married Mary Hulme , a daughter of Thomas Hulme of Cheshire and widow of William Cutler , a Citizen of the City of London . [ 10 ]
#Text=By his wife he had children as follows :
#Text=William Cotton
#Text=( died 1656 ) , eldest son and heir , Rector of Silverton , Archdeacon of Totnes , and Precentor of Exeter Cathedral , all in Devon .
#Text=He married Elizabeth Hender , a daughter and co-heiress of John Hender of Botreaux Castle , Cornwall . [ 11 ]
#Text=Edward Cotton
#Text=( died 1647 ) , Rector of Shobrooke and Archdeacon of Totnes , both in Devon .
#Text=He married Margaret Bruton ( alias Breton ) daughter of William Bruton of Heavitree , near Exeter .
#Text=His monument survives in Shobrooke Church . [ 12 ]
#Text=Judith Cotton , wife firstly of Freeman Page of Finchley in Middlesex , secondly of Roger Coniers of Finchley , Hertfordshire ( sic ) . [ 13 ]
#Text=Death and burial
#Text=He died on 6 August 1621 and was buried in Exeter Cathedral where his fine monument with recumbent effigy survives .
